result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Benjamin Roy Everson

records.addlTxt:
2:26 PM 
Defendant Benjamin Roy Everson in court.  Attorney Adam Thomas Witt in court for Benjamin Roy Everson.  Attorney Jenna L Gill in court for State of Wisconsin. 
Attorney Witt informs the court his client wishes to waive his right to preliminary hearing.
Court informs the defendant of his right to preliminary hearing and purpose of said hearing.
Court questions defendant re: his right to preliminary hearing.
Parties stipulate to a factual basis.
Court questions counsel re: their clients waiver of preliminary hearing.
Court finds waiver of preliminary is made freely, knowingly & voluntarily.
Court accepts waiver and orders bind over. 

"NOT GUILTY" entered. 

Attorney Witt informs the court these matters are resolved and moves for plea/sentencing.
Plea/sentencing hearing scheduled for December 12, 2022 at 03:45 pm.
Plea/sentencing hearing on December 12, 2022 at 03:45 pm.
Preliminary hearing on October 24, 2022 at 02:00 pm.
